column4: what file system should I partition an external HDD so both Windows and Linux can read/write to it?
does NTFS work?
NTFS works, but is proprietary
you can use ext3, but then you have to download an extra tool for Windows (e.g. ext2fsd)
I suggest you back up everything with Linux, even Windows data. Then you can use the best file system for large files and large contiguous reads and writes, which is currently XFS.
Freecom FSG-3
no
I've never used XFS
it's a matter of technical limitations. ext3 is okay under Windows with ext2fsd
I would be the one performing all the backups from my Linux lappy. My wife is the one that uses Windows and has some photos that would need to be backed up mostly
I guess I could just transfer the photos from her Windows lappy to my Linux comp and then backup/sync them from here
so why not backup the Windows data while you're booted into Linux?
oh, I see, you've got different machines
you could of course partition the backup drive and have both NTFS and ext3 on it
I'm trying to get her to convert over to the dark side...and replace XP with Intrepid
she just uses proprietary apps which require Window$ for her work
that's too much to have multiple partitions and filesystems
I think I'm just going to go ext3 and use that driver for Windows
have you considered a NAS box for backing up?
yeah I was looking into that originally, but it was cost prohibitive
I'm using an external USB 2.0 HDD for now
I found the Freecom offer reasonable
